newsitem.title: USA: Netscape up on "crossware" road map.
newsitem.headline: Netscape up on "crossware" road map.

text.p: Shares of Netscape Communications Corp jumped by nearly 12 percent after the company unveiled a "road map" for its next-generation products.
Netscape shares closed up 3-1/8 points at 29-5/8, with more than 3.7 million shares traded, making it among the 20 most active Nasdaq market shares.

"The point of today's road map was really to show that Netscape understands and will extend the vision of what it means to be an enterprise into 21st century," said Hambrecht & Quist analyst Daniel Rimer.

Goldman Sachs analyst Michael Parekh, in a research note issued this morning, also said he was reiterating his rating on the stock -- which is on the firm's recommended list -- noting Netscape shares has been trading at their lowest since the company's initial public offering in August 1995.

Parekh said this week's Internet World conference in Los Angeles will likely be a showcase for Netscape's upcoming Communicator 4.0 and SuiteSpot 3.0 product suites, which are due to be shipping as full products in the June quarter.
Parekh said Netscape could be in its strongest-ever product position in the second half of 1997 if it can meet its technical, marketing and support challenges.
Parekh said in the note that he expects first quarter revenues to grow nominally from the fourth quarter of 1996, up one percent to $116.7 million, and expects growth to increase later in the year.

H&Q's Rimer said that, despite Netscape's current product transition, he estimates revenues will be $120 million in the current first quarter, with earnings per share of $0.08, which would be up from earnings per share pf $0.06 a year ago.

Earlier today, Netscape outlined its strategy to provide Internet-based software it calls "crossware" to companies that will use it to communicate among themselves on various projects, such as with customers and suppliers.

Marc Andreessen, Netscape's co-founder and senior vice president of technology, said in an interview that this market could be even larger than the market for internal corporate networks using Internet software, known as "intranets".
Some independent research firms have said the intranet software market could grow to some $10 billion by the year 2000, only three years from now.

Netscape said the company's next generation software, which would include cross-entity collaboration capabilities for what Andreessen calls "extranets" -- will be available in test versions later this year and delivered in 1998.

Rimer said the company's plans were "extending the barrier between what separated Netscape as the definer of the vision (of Internet technology) and the companies who are trying to follow that vision, namely Microsoft and Lotus."

Shares of Microsoft, which is working on a new version of its rival Internet Explorer browser software, rose 3-1/4 to 100 and International Business Machines Corp, which owns Lotus Development Corp., gained 1-1/4 to 146. Rimer added that, despite the enthusiasm for using Internet software in corporate settings, a recent H&Q survey of 50 information technology managers of Fortune 200 companies found that 71 percent expected intranet software to account for less than two percent of their annual technology budgets.

Rimer said this was a sign intranet software is still relatively inexpensive relative to older systems that companies must continue to maintain and he noted that most calculate nearly immediate payback from Internet technology.
"Intranet software is very cheap," Rimer said.
